noun.description: A rhetorical figure by which an opponent's objections are anticipated and answered.

origin: Late 16th century. From post-classical Latin procatalepsis rhetorical figure by which an opponent's objections are anticipated and answered from ancient Greek προκατάληψις, lit. seizing in advance from προ- + κατάληψις seizing, after προκαταλαμβάνειν to seize beforehand, to anticipate.
